Is it not weird, for native English-speakers, that we don't even consider English a language? We don't even have to think about the words before we say them, because we just grew up learning how to speak English. But there are people all over the world who have the same situation, but with the other, like, 6,999 languages. I LOVE thinking about how cool that is. And how fluently we can speak English, but how people around the world can do the same thing with Spanish or French or Danish or Polish or Finnish, and those people wouldn't even understand us when we have our conversations, and vice versa ITS SO COOL TO THINK ABOUT

3:10 one particular facet of accents is rhoticity and non-rhoticity. A rhotic accent like that of Michael Stevens, has all R sounds pronounced in no matter where the ' R ' appears in a word. A non-rhotic accent has the 'R' sound dropped or unpronounced after vowel sounds. Non rhotic accents include RP (basically "standard" British English ), Australian accents, some southern American accents, New England accents ( most notably Boston ), the accents native to NYC, most of New Zealand and parts of India. Rhotic accents include most American accents, Scottish and Irish accents, some varieties of English in India, areas of New Zealand and 99.9% of Canada.

Now, the rhoticity or non-rhoticity of an accent is not always absolute. For example, almost all non rhotic American accents pronounce the Rs in words like ' bird ' ' work ' and ' girl ' even if the accent is otherwise non rhotic. Moreover, most southern American accents and NYC accents have inconsistent rhoticity, this means that Rs sometimes get pronounced after vowel sounds and sometimes the Rs get dropped.

Examples of rhotic and non rhotic word differences

Rhotic
Car
There
Merely
Letter

Non rhotic
Cah
thea or theyuh
Meely or me-uhly
Lettuh or letta

Many languages use the Roman writing system. But why are letters pronounced other ways in other languages. There are less languages which have the same pronounciation for every letter where ever it was than there are languages which have changing pronounciations for letters where all is about the location of the letter. For an example, in Finnish language the letter "e" is pronounced the same way even though it was in the beginning, in the middle or the ending of the word. In English, the pronounciation of the letter "e" is different in words "east", "game", "test" and "Europe". In Finnish language there are no problems, spelling and pronounciation is the same. The tendre croppes, and the yonge sonne

Interesting, but in a nutshell, modern English is the combination of Anglo-Saxon German and French. This video is correct in saying the pivotal year was 1066. That's when William the Conqueror, a Frenchman, claimed the Anglo-Saxon throne, albeit on loose grounds, but, hey, the victor makes the rules. For many years, the common folk still spoke Anglo-Saxon German, but the court language was French. Eventually, the two merged, creating English. The difference is not hard to tell. Most fancy words in English derive from French. The simple, in-your-face words, are likely German. About 98 percent of the most common English words you use are Anglo-Saxon German. And, he he, all the four-letter dirty words are definitely A-S German.

“Before they had Latin characters, they wrote their language, not in letters, but in runes.”

The Angles maybe, but the Latin alphabet came to Britain with the Romans, long before any runes arrived. The Latin script predates runes, also in Britain. 

Most sources indicate that he English language evolved mostly from Frisian, by the way, more than from the languages (/dialects) of the Angles or the Saxons. The Frisians had settled along the East coast of Britain since the Romans left and I would not be surprised if they were the ones who brought over Angles and Saxons in search of land. The last two names have continued in English history, but the Frisians are rarely mentioned, and that is regrettable. 

The Frisian influence on the English nation goes beyond language, I think. The Frisians are known for their cool (not easily impressed), for their understatements and their dry sense of humour, all characteristics for which the English are also known. After the Romans withdrew, roads became unsafe, but Frisians took over the trade, because they had sailing boats. Thus they became rich trading overseas in boats, a trick they have passed on to the Dutch and the English. We owe much to the Frisians.

Unlike the land-loving Franks, who introduced feudalism,  and unlike many of the other nations, seafaring Frisians were (and are) quite egalitarian. Has that survived in the English character?

English has become the de facto international language. This has happened due to three major reasons:

1. Of the most widely spoken languages on the planet, English is the easiest one to learn.

2. English is the language of the internet AND the web (yes, the two are not the same thing). Both were invented and developed by English speaking people, in English speaking countries. Today, the vast majority of the content on the internet exists in English.

3. English is the language of science, engineering and technology. The vast majority of scientific and engineering papers around the globe are published in English, regardless of their country of origin. Today, it is virtually impossible for someone to be a real scientist or engineer without a reasonable proficiency of the English language. 

It is not unreasonable to think that in 50-100 years, if humanity is to emerge as a single global community, it will do so while adopting a common language, and that language will be English.

Someone below commented that the etymology of the word 'pig' is really hard to figure out - but it seems not to be so. A simple Google search reveals that "pig" probably came from the Old English word "picbréd", meaning "acorn", which was then adapted in Middle English to refer to swine-food, thus the word "pig" was very likely back-formed from "picbréd" or "pig-bread" (the '-bred' part of "picbréd" being naturally confused for the almost identical sounding 'bread'), and thus the word for swine-food became a new word for the swines themselves.

The etymology of 'dog', however, is less clear. It came from the Old English "docga", which originally referred to a very rare and specific powerful breed of "hund" (hound) - but where exactly the word "docga" comes from - ?. All that is sure is that it mostly displaced the Germanic "hund", so that now in English "hound" doesn't necessarily refer to every kind of dog, but mostly hunting breeds in particular. (interesting that in Old High Germanic the cognate for hound/hund is "hunt", which is identical in sound and spelling to the English verb "hunt" - perhaps because long ago dogs and hunting were even more closely linked). The word "canine" is of course Latin, from caninus --> canis (and so the French "chien" and the Italian "cane"). But the origin of Spanish "perro" is mysterious - probably from a long-forgotten Iberian tongue.

Some stuff kinda makes sense, especially when it comes to new technologies, they need names for them and sometimes mixing English words together doesn't really work great. A great example of this I think is storage capacity in computers, KiloByte, MegaByte, Giga, , Tera, Peta and so on, all the first parts are derived from Latin while Byte or sort of a direved word from bit or the plural for bits. I may be wrong on some of this but it is interesting.
Also, English spelling is similar as well, for example a place called "ye olde inn" would actually still be pronounced as the old inn back in its time. They just didn't have the spellings we have today.
In the future though, I can see a lot of words being added to the English language which is abbreviated and/or shortened with and without apostrophes.
It amazes me how dynamic the language can actually be, however it would be interesting to know if the same sort of things happen in other languages too.

So having a different name for the animal and the meat from it is rare? Interesting. I never thought that the different naming is unique, as my native language (Slovak) has this difference too:
Cow/Beef - Krava/Hovädzie
Chicken/Poultry - Sliepka/Hydina (Hydina referring also to Turkey and other birds)
Pig/Pork - Prasa (or Ošípané)/Bravčové (but I heared the term Brav for a pig, but it is not common)
Deer/Venison - this is specific, we use the equivalent of the english word "Game" (Divina) or "Venison" (Zverina) and then the respecitve name of animal - the difference is if the animal was hunted in the wild then it is Divina (Game) but when it was sort of farmed like livestock in a closed part of a forest then it is Zverina (Venison). Maybe I get the meaning of Game and Venison wrong thoug...
sheep/mutton - this is specific, we use the word jahňacie meaning lamb for lamb and sheep, but the male sheep ram is baran and the meat from him is generally baranie (or baranina) reffering directly to the animal

It's an informal combination of one of the "to be" verbs (am, are, and is) and not. So, if someone were to say "I am not smart", it would be "I ain't smart". I'm not positive as to where it came from, but I believe it's a derivation of the old contraction "an't", which is no longer is use today. An't previously meant "am not" or "are not", so my guess is someone threw an "i" into it to account for "is not", and this "ain't" was born. Again, however, that part I'm not positive about.
In about 300 years from now, English is going to sound really different...

It's a slang contraction. The normal contraction is "isn't", which is a combination of is and not. "Ain't", on the other hand, is not a contraction of two words but simply slang. It's as much a word as "yo" (which is not a word).

No, they weren't.  Viking, from Norse "víkingr" (meaning sea-faring), were just northern Germanic people's who raided, traded, and explored areas beyond their settled lands.  Vikings were just normal every day Northern Germanic farmers, average people, who might go on a raid, or an adventure at certain times, and thus be called víkingr.  They were also known as Ascomanni, meaning ash men, for their burning.  But not all Scandinavians were víkingr.  Viking was reserved for people who raided.
They're all Germanic.  Which explains the commonalities in language and, yes, the runes.

A lot of English has Celtic in it too, which are the Irish, Scottish and Welsh parts of the British Isles. The Angles nor the Saxons had any impact on the Celts as they only invaded England. So their language developed independently as Welsh and Gaelic (still spoken today) and often integrated into English as dialects of English. Thats why  particularly the Irish and the Scots have such a hugely different accent from "British", and and are people often forget they are British (except Eire now)

Actually, no. Colonial dialects always are more conservative and reflect the era they diverged. N. American reflects 18th Century English, Aussie early 19th Century, etc. Modern British dialect characteristics reflect shifts that started post-1800. Pronouncing T in often, dropping final R, glottal stopping TT in little, et al., all started in Victorian times. If a Brit went back 300 years his English would sound absurd to native speakers. But so would anyone's today.

Most people only use a fraction of those words on a daily basis (maybe several hundred, or several thousand). A very large portion of those "600,000 words" are highly specialized jargon (the stuff you hear physicists and doctors and linguists, etc., speaking with, which many people have difficulty understanding). Some of those words also go out of common usage - languages are not a "Dead Sea" of words. But I would expect people to be speaking differently in 100 years, yes.
So you can't speak the local American accent fluently? Do people often ask you if you're from the UK, then?

Neither word comes from German, but they both come from a Germanic language (Old English, which came from West Germanic, which came from Proto-Germanic). All Germanic languages are closely related to each other (some more closely than others). Some documented Germanic languages are: English, Old English, Modern German, Modern Low German, Old High German, Old Saxon (Old Low German), Afrikaans, Dutch, Old Dutch, Frisian, Icelandic, Norwegian, Swedish, Danish, Gothic, Old Norse, Old Frisian, Scots.

That's a tall order. There are at least dozens, if not hundreds, of clearly distinguishable accents in English, some of which are not easily mutually intelligible. The simple answer to why they're different, though, is: Language change is completely normal, so when different communities are largely isolated, it is highly likely that they will have different language changes (resulting in different accents, or dialects, and even different languages - for example, German and English are related).
Look up "History of the English Language" on Wikipedia. Or get a book out of your local library. It's really not so hard to find this stuff out.

For added fun, our months are courtesy of the Romans while our days of the week are a right old mixture of Roman, proto-Germanic, Norse and Old English deities: Sun's day, Moon's day, Tiw's day (Norse equivalent of Mars), Woden's day (Germanic equivalent of Mercury), Thunarr's day (Old English, derived from the Norse god Thor, derived from proto-Germanic god Thunraz - thunder, equivalent of Jupiter), Frijj's day (Old English equivalent of Norse Freya, equivalent of Venus), Saturn's day.

The Normans were also responsible for Francophonic spellings (e.g. centre) which are still preserved in Merrie Olde England but were reversed by Noah Webster when compiling his dictionary thus giving rise to the oxymoronic terms "US English" and "British English".

This is often used as a classic example of how English has a lot of words that don't follow rules. A tongue/palate placement graphic will only go part way to explaining pronunciation for English.

once they see what letter corresponds to what tongue movement they will be able to read documents on the rules of english such as (gasp) a grammar textbook or similar, showing them how to deal with silent letters

The features used to describe sounds are based on the human anatomy, similar to how the chart in the video works, only more precise and not bundled with letters. Because of that the symbols can be explained using images and videos. The symbol for the th-sound could be explained by showing someone put his tongue on his teeth, producing an airstream and causing his vocal folds to vibrate. You can do that for all the symbols of the IPA charts.

If the language is dead, there's no sure fire way. But we seem to have done a pretty good job of figuring out what people from before our time were trying to say with their writing, so I have faith in our distant descendants. Especially if they have a pronunciation map of their own mouths and some dictionaries to go with it.
There is no reason to use any symbols other than our own, because they wouldn't be able to read all of our information with what they were given.

What kind of symbols do you want to use?
Letters are not a good choice in my opinion, because they are used in written language, which is not that closely related with how the words are actually said.

Well, we can't write it in the future persons' language. All we can do is preserve as much precise information as we can. Dictionaries focussing on meaning, writing and pronunciation separately and material that helps to explain them without using language (images and videos) would obviously be the best option.
We know much more about ancient Egypt language's meaning than we know about how it sounded, precisely because the records on it were about meaning, not pronunciation.
That's like saying we could have learned hieroglyphics if the Egyptians had left us a pronunciation dictionary written in hieroglyphics. It makes absolutely no sense.

...Dude...Really? That's what I was responding to. A diagram makes sense. German has: der, die, das, den, dem, des. Essentially there are 16, because all those 6 articles get used in different places at different times. Like "den" can be both the masculine singular in the accusative case, or the plural in the dative case.  Der too, can either be the nominative masculine, the dative feminine, or the feminine genitive. And then depending on which article and case you have, it changes the endings on adjectives, and again there are like 16 endings for adjectives. Total BS

The reason English spelling is so hard is because 1) it gets its spelling rules from a bunch of different languages, & 2) English is unique in that both one spelling can have multiple pronunciations AND one phoneme can be written in many ways. For most other languages with alphabets, it's either one or the other. For example, in French, the same phoneme can be written many ways, but when you read something, you know how to pronounce it. Latin (IIRC) tends to do the opposite.

Actually reading Greek is perfectly regular even without knowledge of Ancient Greek. Writing in Greek requires knowledge of where the word comes from in order to spell it correctly though. This does not prevent a person who does not have that knowledge from reading it correctly.

The "k" in "knob" is indeed silent. Same with the "g" in "gnaw". At some point they probably were pronounced but later on they were "dropped" from pronunciation but they probably kept the spelling for historical reasons and so that it would not be confused with "no" (presumably). The "e" in "clothes" needs to be there otherwise "th" would not be pronounced as in "this" but as in "thesis" which would be wrong. Similarly the "o" would be pronounced as in "pot" (also wrong) instead of as in "mode".

French is more regular in its pronunciation but the damned silent letters in french, which are truly silent in this case are all in the last syllable. As a person who learnt french I can honestly say that the greatest difficulty there is knowing how much of the word to pronounce and how much not to. Spanish is more regular in its pronunciation as it has no silent ones and the entire word is pronounced. Same with german. Greek is totally regular if you know ancient greek.

I sympathize as english is not my mother tong. The thing is for example if the "e" was not in vineyard the "i" would not be pronounced as "ay" but as "i" as in "pin". So you see there is some logic in some of the so called silent ones. The "e" in vineyard is not pronounced granted but because it moderates how another letter is pronounced in the same word I would call it a modal letter. Same with "gh" in "thought" which is pronounced slightly differently to "thot" which does not exist in english.

I just wanted to add something:
The Angles were followed by Saxons and Jutes - which meant that when they settled their differences, they spoke either German or Danish. Danes took the power somewhere between 300-500 - bringing even more Danish to the language. And in 860 (or so) more Danes migrated, and brought down the Anglo-Saxons, and instated Danelaw. Which meant more Danish. Great examples of the words derived from Danish are:
Egg-Æg
Warm-Varm
Cold-Koldt
Hope-Håb

As someone training to be a speech pathologist, I really enjoyed this video. However it is important to understand the difference between accent and dialect, which many people get wrong. 
Accent is taking rules from one language and applying it to another, while Dialects are variations of a common language. So instead of a southern accent it’s a southern dialect.
